text: CHRIS MOODY: San Francisco--

the crown jewel of
California's northern coastline

and a hub for Silicon Valley's
thriving technology industry.

If you're one of the millions
of business travelers to the Bay

Area and want to meet
some of the locals,

we've got a trip for
you, and it's just a 30
minute drive from downtown.

VANESSA YURKEVICH:
I'm Vanessa Yurkevich.

CHRIS MOODY: And
I'm Chris Moody.

We travel a ton for
work, and so do you.

VANESSA YURKEVICH: But you can
still get in a bit of adventure

before you have to hop
back on that plane.

CHRIS MOODY: Built on a
Cold War missile site,

the Marine Mammal Center is
just across the Golden Gate
Bridge in the Marin Headlands.

CLAIRE SIMEONE: We are
the largest marine mammal
hospital in the world.

We rescue animals
along about 700
miles of the California coast.

Any time we get a call
from a member of the public

that an animal is
sick or injured,

then one of our
volunteers will go

out and rescue them and
bring him into our hospital.

We see primarily pinnipeds,
which are seals and sea lions,

and right now, we'll
see northern elephant

seals, harbor seals, and
California sea lions.

CHRIS MOODY: The Center is
free and open to visitors,
and they also need some help.

The Center cares for hundreds
of animals at a time,

so volunteers are needed,
especially in the kitchen.

CLAIRE SIMEONE: This
is a place where people

can come if they just
have a couple of hours
to help feed our animals.
They can help us to sort fish.

They can help us to
prep things, to wash

dishes, the whole
gamut, to really have
an impact for our patients.

CHRIS MOODY: How much fish
do you all go through a day?

CLAIRE SIMEONE: When we're
in our busiest season,

we can go through 1,000
pounds of fish a day.

This is the topside
area, which is

where we have our elephant seal
patients and our sea lions.

Our volunteer crews are bringing
out the fish milkshakes,

the fish mash, and the
equipment that they're going
to use to feed the animals.

CHRIS MOODY: I've never
had a fish milkshake,

but I imagine it's
delicious for them.
CLAIRE SIMEONE: They love it.

CHRIS MOODY: This is not a
zoo, but it's an authentic way

to encounter live animals
from the Bay Area,

and it's part of
the mission here

to ensure the animals can return
to nature when they're healthy.

CLAIRE SIMEONE: It's
a really great place

to come if you have
a couple of hours,

and you really want to see
some marine mammals up close.
